answers.author: Brian Halverson
answers.text:
I don't work directly for the Fleet Department, but I am the Solid Waste Department Fleet Analyst.  I've been looking into this exact question, and based on my research, I would recommend the following:

Availability: Percentage of time the equipment is up and running during the hours it is needed (e.g. a refuse truck would have 100% availability if it were fully functioning during the hours of collection, say 6:30a to 5p).
Utilization: The number of miles/hours a piece of equipment is being used compared to other equipment of the same class/relative age.
Maintenance/Repair Ratio:  The percentage of total maintenance and repair costs that is spent on PM work as opposed to repairs or unscheduled maintenance.

I am sure there are many other good measures, but these are the ones I generally see consultants, and industry groups recommending.

answers.author: Thomas Quist
answers.text:
I think Brian's recommendations are solid.  Here are a couple of other things I'd be interested in knowing:

Fuel Efficiency of Fleet (slice into groups as you please, such as by department)
Repeat Repairs (incidents where a vehicle is sent back to the shop for the same problems twice within a specified time period)
Hours Billed/Hours Worked for Fleet Services Personnel:  Our garage is set up as an internal service fund and departments are billed for work.  I would think that fleet personnel should be spending most of their time billing - otherwise you may be overstaffed.

Hope this is helpful!

answers.author: Brian Wolverton
answers.text:
We look at:
-Average age of current fleet, broken out by vehicles & heavy equipment
-Average age of vehicles when retired, also broken out
-% of repairs sourced-out to private shops (# and $)
-Mechanic-to-vehicle ratio
-Ratio of unscheduled repairs to preventive maintenance
-Fleet repair costs as a % of estimated private sector costs
-Fuel efficiency of fleet
-Availability
We're just starting our performance measurement program with Fleet, so many of these measures will prove challenging in terms of getting data collection protocols in place, and DPW union guys aren't the easiest to work with on performance measurement, but we're hoping for the best!

answers.author: Zane Reynolds
answers.text:
Performance of Fleet Management departments is one service area that we survey annually as a part of the ICMA's Center for Performance Measurement. CPM has over 180 local government participants nationwide, so we have a fairly comprehensive representation of fleet managers from all over. As a part of our survey effort we asked all of our participants to suggest which measures they felt were 'core' to determining the performance of a fleet management system. Here is what they came up with: 
-Hours Billed per Vehicle or Piece of Equipment Maintained by the Central Fleet Management Operation
-Hours Billed as a Percentage of Hours Available
-Total maintenance expenditures vs. preventative maintenance for each class of vehicles (Does preventive maintenance really hold down the costs of unexpected repairs?)
- Expenditures per mile for each class vehicle
- % of vehicles exceeding a pre-specified replacement criteria
- Employees rating of the quality of fleet management services (employees from other departments.)
With any of these measures you really need to be careful of the amount of difficulty involved with collecting the measures. At CPM we have avoided using availability as a measure, because we find that for many of our participants that number is just too difficult to count. Instead we encourage our participants to set replacement criteria, then track how many vehicles fall outside that criteria. Also, while measuring down time may tell you what percentage of the time a vehicle is available for use, it does not indicate how this timeliness is perceived by the customers (other departmental staff). Ultimately, it is these employees who are the deciding factor in whether the fleet maintenance department is providing them with the tools that they need to serve their constituents and get their job done. That is why we encourage all of our jurisdictions to survey all of their employees in order to determine the performance of internal service areas.
For more information on CPM and internal surveys visit: www.icma.org/performance and http://icma.org/en/results/surveying/
